content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The findings section follows. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. Policies should encourage global technology standards, respect user privacy and security, promote innovation, and avoid restricting Internet service providers. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against the goal of a free, open Internet, such as mandating technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring the unauthorized use of Internet-related tools. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that hinder a free, open Internet. This includes sponsoring unauthorized use of Internet tools to disrupt networks, blocking Internet communications from other countries, monitoring Internet use infringing on privacy, and imposing discriminatory market access requirements on Internet-related goods and services. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that hinder a free, open Internet by imposing discriminatory market access requirements on Internet-related goods and services. These actions threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating attempts to restrict the free flow of information, promoting "national Internets" that conflict with the Internet's original vision, and harming US workers and businesses while giving foreign competitors an advantage. The curr_chunk highlights the risks of undermining the US industrial base, giving foreign competitors an advantage, and jeopardizing the utility of the Internet for open communication and commerce. The curr_chunk introduces the establishment of a Task Force on the Global Internet. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. The President selects a Chairperson from members with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, nominated by the public and appointed by the President. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. Members are appointed by the President and serve renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. Additionally, individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties are appointed by the Senate and House leaders to serve on the Task Force. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established within the executive branch and hosted by the Department of Commerce, appoints members for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force includes individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties appointed by the Senate and House leaders, as well as representatives from various Federal agencies designated by the President. Upon request, Federal officials may be detailed to assist the Task Force. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established within the executive branch and hosted by the Department of Commerce, can have personnel or services detailed from Federal departments to assist in its functions. The Task Force is responsible for developing strategies to address government policies that restrict international trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content, impede the free flow of information, or threaten the open nature of the Internet. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established by the Department of Commerce, is tasked with developing strategies to address government policies that restrict international trade in Internet-related goods, impede information flow, and threaten the open nature of the Internet. The Task Force consults with civil society groups, coordinates federal departments, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints civilian members. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established by the Department of Commerce, appoints a civilian member to lead and serve as a point of contact for inquiries related to its activities. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force must provide an annual report and action plan to the President and Congress, identifying acts that hinder fair market access and trade in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force annual report and action plan must identify measures that threaten US interests in global Internet communications, estimate their impact on commerce and free expression, and prioritize concerns. The Task Force annual report and action plan must identify priority concerns regarding Internet users and the functioning of the Internet. It includes setting forth a strategy for Federal departments and agencies to respond to these concerns and providing information on actions taken in response to previous reports. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed necessary, and public participation is encouraged in the preparation of each annual report and action plan. The Task Force, in preparing annual reports and action plans, must seek public participation, consult with relevant government departments, and share information with civil society groups. The Task Force must consult with government departments, share information with civil society groups, and consider input from the United States Trade Representative for their reports and action plans. They will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding information transmitted under subsection (b). SEC. 5. The United States Trade Representative will initiate investigations and take actions under sections 301 through 304 of the Trade Act of 1974 within 30 days of each annual report transmission, focusing on foreign government practices identified as priority concerns. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice will conduct reviews and investigations. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General will review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. Antitrust laws include the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE AGREEMENTS. The Task Force must submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of this Act's enactment. The report will assess existing trade agreements' effectiveness in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods and services, encouraging global technology standards, protecting Internet security and functionality, facilitating information flow, and safeguarding Internet users' interests. It will also recommend modifications or new agreements to enhance these objectives. The Task Force will recommend modifications or new agreements to advance the objectives of promoting international trade in Internet-related goods and services, encouraging global technology standards, protecting Internet security, facilitating information flow, and safeguarding Internet users' interests. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals, and the report may contain a classified annex if deemed necessary. Public participation will be sought through notices in the Federal Register and public hearings during the report preparation process. The Task Force will consult with relevant departments, agencies, and civil society groups with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. They will also establish a website for public comments, hold public hearings, and consider information from various sources for their activities. The Task Force will coordinate training with various entities for government officials and standard-setting bodies on best practices. They will also consult with outside organizations.
